item.title: A working Agritech partnership. Omnia talks about innovation and transformation in their business.
item.excerpt:encoded: Omnia is a true South African success story. The Group extracts operational synergies and efficiencies across its businesses, and has been in business since 1953 and is listed in the Chemicals sector of the Johannesburg Securities Exchange. .

item.title: Entelect and POWERX unlocking potential within South Africa's renewable energy market
item.excerpt:encoded: Entelect recently completed a digitization project to enable one of South Africa's most interesting and pioneering companies to scale their operations. Here is the story behind our partnership with POWERX, creating a software platform to drive and automate processes as the business prepared to capitalize on a freshly-proven business model.

item.title: Entelect and Sage BEE123: A holistic view to solution engineering
item.excerpt:encoded: Saul Symanowitz (MD, Sage BEE123) discusses the technical partnership with Entelect and the journey undertaken to develop this nationally recognised and unique product: Sage BEE123, a BEE scorecard and scenario planning solution.

item.title: The data science behind driver behaviour
item.excerpt:encoded: Insure Telematics Solutions is a remarkable motor telematics organisation offering data-driven driver behaviour analytics and tools spanning first notification of loss (FNOL), claim insights and risk modelling. For the last few years, Entelect has shared an exciting technology journey building and refining the models and technology that underpin these services. From crash-alert algorithms able to accurately distinguish true incidents from false ones to the recreation of an incident through data, it is safe to say we’ve had our hands full cleverly collecting, storing and transforming data to provide an intelligence offering that is poised to drive their business forward

item.title: Streamlining the medical student placement process at Stellenbosch University
item.excerpt:encoded: The faculty of Health and Medical Sciences at Stellenbosch University partnered with Entelect to revamp their placement process. The project was to design and develop a software application that supports the faculty in the management of student placements at training facilities as part of their clinical training. The solution extends to full curriculum management to accurately track resource utilisation and enable cost recovery from state funding.

item.title: Entrepreneurs need open cloud, not protectionism
item.excerpt:encoded: South Africa desperately needs to encourage entrepreneurship as a means to addressing the country’s job creation targets. A report issued by FNB and the Gordon Institute of Business Science (GIBS) states that “the most competitive nations are those that have the highest level of entrepreneurial activity.” The Total Entrepreneurial Activity (TEA) is a measurement of the percentage of the active population in a country (people aged between 25 and 64) who are entrepreneurs. According to International Entrepreneurship, South Africa’s TEA in 2010 is 8.9%. This is higher than in previous years and significantly higher than our average TEA over the past decade: 6.7%. If South Africa wants to be a meaningful player in the global economy, we have to shape education, society and legislation to encourage, rather than stifle, entrepreneurship.

item.title: Make your business a success by living your values
item.excerpt:encoded: Dr Charles Pritchard, Entelect CEO, was recently interviewed by Entrepreneurmag. Here's a taster of an upcoming feature. He outlines the importance of knowing your limitations, listening to others and avoiding being everything to everyone. He emphasizes the importance of following ones heart and pushing this through, but always taking guidance from top management who often see things differently and may have a more sober insight in particular areas. Most importantly he sticks to the motto of hiring the best, and living ones values - something he believes is the key ingredient to Entelect's continued growth and success.

item.title: Software skills trending in 2014
item.excerpt:encoded: The software industry is renowned for moving at breakneck speed – a three-week holiday can see you returning to work and being neck-deep in new terminology, technology and techniques. It has become critical as a software engineer to stay abreast of technological advances, specifically the tools, processes and platforms to which you may be exposed. This will enable you to identify the best tool or framework for a job and it will also help you justify your decisions.

item.title: You can’t ‘outsource’ love
item.excerpt:encoded: Sam Wright at Tech Girl recently interviewed Entelect CEO, Dr Charles Pritchard. Pritchard asserts that companies need to take ownership of their own community-support initiatives. Although there is a place for allocating budgets to NGOs that support the poor, he suggests that it is far more effective if company employees also become involved in supporting their beneficiaries.

item.title: Matthew Butler (Entelect Software: General Manager)
item.excerpt:encoded: The risks and vulnerabilities associated with having an online presence are nothing new, so why then do we,especially within our South African context, continue to see daily reports of breaches, leaks, data-loss, hacking and defacement of sometimes very high profile web sites?

item.title: What do South Africans have against ICT?
item.excerpt:encoded: After speaking to various friends, family members and clients about the subject, it seems that very few South Africans consider careers in software development or information and communication technologies (ICT) when leaving school.

item.title: Choosing the right company for you – part two
item.excerpt:encoded: There are many factors that need to be considered when looking for that perfect company for you. In part one of this series of articles, the determining factors we looked at included the size, track record and staff development of a company. So, what else should you consider?

item.title: Choosing the right company for you – part one
item.excerpt:encoded: So, your CV is ready, you are prepped for the interview process and you are about to start sending out your CV… but wait, there are so many companies! How do you choose where you want to work? How do you know which company will suit you best? Here are some things that should be considered when choosing a company to work for – and yes, good professionals are in demand, so you can be picky.

item.title: Dis-Intra-rupt: The new age of business and looking inwards
item.excerpt:encoded: Every single conference that I attended in 2015 had at least one speaker talking about disruption. At my last conference, it became a drinking game from the obligatory conference Valpré water bottle. Hear the word “disruption”, drink another sip, sit back and watch the old-school, brick and mortar enterprises try to catch up to a technology wave moving with speed.

item.title: Building an effective software environment
item.excerpt:encoded: To get the best out of their engineers, many firms create the ‘ideal’ place for staff to work. They install creative spaces, televisions that are tuned to news or live events, and state- of-the-art meeting rooms. Some also offer fantastic perks and rewards. How important are these to creating an effective software environment? Are there other, more important, factors to consider?

item.title: Finding the right offshoring partner
item.excerpt:encoded: Offshoring companies’ software development needs is becoming common place, particularly as global communication improves and the disparity in technical ability between Western and other countries narrows. So how can companies be sure to outsource to the best-equipped software development company?

item.title: Offshoring to South Africa – a beneficial engagement
item.excerpt:encoded: South Africa is increasingly a competitive player when it comes to offering software development outsourcing to global companies and the country has some world-class software developers and software development companies.

item.title: Software start-ups - succeeding before you start
item.excerpt:encoded: Starting a business based on a software product is no easy task. Almost daily, our team is asked by individuals with grand ideas (ridiculous, novel or brilliant) on how to get started with a software-based business. If you're an entrepreneur with all the passion for the business aspects of your new endeavour, don’t be deterred by the mammoth task that is software development, we’ve put together our top tips for anyone starting up in the software development space.

item.title: Six tips for a perfect outsourced software solution
item.excerpt:encoded: Outsourcing is becoming an increasingly popular way to power your latest visionary idea in-house. However, how can you be sure that you’ll end up with exactly what you want, before you run out of money?

item.title: Building High Performing Teams
item.excerpt:encoded: In the software engineering space, the teams are a critical success factor of projects. But what features define a High Performance Team?

item.title: Corporate IT: Thoughts on staying relevant and becoming competitive
item.excerpt:encoded: The tech-startup eco-system has driven the demand for fast-paced agile and lean software practices and an incredible amount of innovation. But, how do we make sure we’re delivering against industry’s best practices and leveraging the benefits of modern tools to stay competitive?

item.title: Building High Performance Teams: Part 2 – The 3C’s
item.excerpt:encoded: Beyond certain operational features that contribute to team success, there are three behaviours; craftsmanship, communication and customer-centricity that should be considered basic ingredients for high-performance teams.

item.title: Why Agile in corporates doesn't work, yet.
item.excerpt:encoded: All CIOs are aware that quality software requires an organisation to follow an Agile development methodology. But Agile development requires a culture shift and full buy-in from the entire organisation.

item.title: Custom software development vs off-the-shelf products, which will help elevate your business ahead of its competitors?
item.excerpt:encoded: How should a business decide whether they should be investing in a customized software solution or an off-the-shelf product?

item.title: Trends in Enterprise Software. What we can expect to see in 2018.
item.excerpt:encoded: We can expect to see several technology trends making waves this year, but the force driving these trends will be the renewed focus on user experience within enterprises mimicking consumer offerings.

item.title: Working from home - is there a verdict?
item.excerpt:encoded: Tele-working and Telecommuting are both popular thanks to technology tools that facilitate communication and collaboration. But it doesn’t necessarily mean both deliver the same results in terms of employee engagement and productivity.

item.title: Choose your digital transformation starting point
item.excerpt:encoded: There are many successful Digital Transformation stories out there. According to Gartner, about 66% of leaders want to transform, but only about 11% are actually achieving a healthy dose of digital business. In your quest to Digitally Transform, questions such as “Have we unlocked new digital ways of making money?” or “Can we quantifiably differentiate the way to deliver value to our customers?”. If you answered “No” to either, then your Digital Transformation journey continues.

item.title: Making the most of your 2019 technology budget
item.excerpt:encoded: In recent years it has become critical for Medium Enterprises (MEs) to accurately analyse their technology-related spend to rather detail the desired value-generators. This value perspective aids the decision-making process and also ensures the spend is aligned with the desired organisational goals.

item.title: Reasons to upgrade your legacy systems
item.excerpt:encoded: Upgrading your legacy systems: A digital advantage or giant waste of money? For most enterprises, the thought of upgrading a longstanding legacy system is quite daunting. It can be a highly cumbersome process with lots of moving parts to account for, generally leading to an if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it mindset. The process of upgrading is also infamous for often being a costly exercise – causing many business leaders to cling to their deteriorating systems. When a legacy system still meets the current requirements, it’s hard to justify spending resources to stay up to date.

item.title: A South African perspective on traditional IT versus digital transformation
item.excerpt:encoded: South Africa has quite a few very large and very old organisations. They tend to be quite federated, and a cursory glance over their unique histories explains why. Some departments and business units were acquired or merged, some were started as silos and others just evolved along a different vector. Therein lies a problem of companies with long histories: divergence. Customer channels evolve faster than mainframes, payments evolve faster than compliance, and insurance faster than banking.

item.title: Build and buy: Where custom software belongs in your universe
item.excerpt:encoded: As businesses evolve, they will need software as a foundation of their strategy. Whether it’s a product, supporting a service, or driving efficiency in business processes, there is no avoiding it.

item.title: UX as an important part of your agile delivery team
item.excerpt:encoded: The noteworthy impact design has had on software development in recent times has been indisputable. The market now is absolutely connected, and the network effect means that products with excellent user experiences will go viral, while bad user experiences will have the reverse negative effect.

item.title: The data science behind UX
item.excerpt:encoded: With the technological advancement in the 21st century, everybody wants to experience the best technology with the least amount of effort. By now, user experience (UX) design is recognised as a crucial part of customer satisfaction, but without the relevant data to validate the designs, we’re relying too much on intuition.

item.title: Why Design Sprints fail
item.excerpt:encoded: Developed by Google Ventures, a Design Sprint is a five-day process for answering critical business questions through design, prototyping, and testing ideas with customers or stakeholders. While Design Sprints are great for validating ideas and solving big challenges, they don’t always work. Getting people to clear their schedules for a week is already challenging, even more so when that week results in wasted efforts.

item.title: Best practices for building developer-friendly APIs
item.excerpt:encoded: Application Programming Interfaces (APIs) can be among a company's greatest assets but can also be among their greatest liabilities. Poorly designed APIs lead to an endless queue of consequences followed by a bad reputation.

item.title: But is it art ?
item.excerpt:encoded: Traditionally one of the most common understandings of what the software engineers do on a development team is that they are individuals that turn caffeine and pizza into code. While this usually gets a giggle or two, it is obviously not the whole picture. The fact of the matter is that when it comes to understanding what developers do, very few people can empathise with the “coders” on a team and the role they play in the development process.

item.title: 7 business and technology trends to look out for in 2020
item.excerpt:encoded: Over the past decade, buzzwords like “disruption” and “blockchain” were all the hype, along with some curiosity and confusion around the rise of artificial intelligence and machine learning. The big question for businesses moving into 2020 is how to start leveraging these disruptive technology and business trends.

item.title: When a stranger calls - The hidden generation of digital customers
item.excerpt:encoded: There’s a new generation of customers. Customers who are more informed, more experienced and more digital. And they’re not answering your calls anymore.

item.title: Overcoming human irrationality with UX
item.excerpt:encoded: Forget about your competitors, just focus on your customers.” This seems like a simple-yet-bold statement by Alibaba co-founder, Jack Ma. But do we as organisations really know our customers? Or do we just think that we do?

item.title: Transforming your data deluge from a liability into an asset
item.excerpt:encoded: There has been a considerable focus on amassing and storing data over the past decade: the more data collected, the better. But when the volume of new data being generated is overwhelming the capacity of institutions to manage it and researchers to make use of it, it turns into a data deluge.

item.title: Should you be worried about serverless lock-in?
item.excerpt:encoded: Serverless architecture is the inevitable future for most organisations, as major players in the technology sector are moving towards cloud platforms. This is due to cloud vendors’ abilities to provision and manage major computer resources, and drastically reduce the time-to-market. With the growing interest in serverless architecture, the market is expected to reach $7.7 billion by 2021.

item.title: Optimise-and-shift: Finding value in pragmatic cloud migration
item.excerpt:encoded: The (r)evolution of cloud computing has been a significant focus in industry for the past decade, where organisations are often attracted to the possibility that cloud migration can lead to the benefits of cost savings and flexibility. While cloud benefits are clear, the best model and approach for migration can be less obvious, and organisations frequently waste time on debating this. While the chosen model and approach for a cloud migration is significant, the focus should rather be on optimisation.

item.title: 3 reasons why UX is important for your internal systems
item.excerpt:encoded: Historically – and understandably – the focus for user interface and user experience (UI/UX) has been prioritised for customer-facing software. Naturally, you want your customers to have the best experience possible to drive product differentiation, uptake and retention.

item.title: The growing importance of an executive with technology savvy
item.excerpt:encoded: In today’s business climate, every company’s strategy is anchored around technology. To maintain a competitive edge is to prioritise innovation, and in most instances that translates to some sort of technology.

item.title: The evolving role of IT budgets within large organisations
item.excerpt:encoded: While technology has been a focal point for businesses for some time now, technology budgeting and investment practices have been lagging. With the growing need for digital transformation within large organisations, IT budgets need to shift from a project-to-project execution model to one that is capacity-based and more flexible. IT and software are becoming the products themselves and will be permanently evolving. They cannot be seen as start/stop expenses. In many cases, they are the fuel for the organisations continued growth, or even relevance, and so need to be invested in proportionally.

item.title: Where to start: Managing the pressure to modernise legacy systems
item.excerpt:encoded: Most large enterprise executives have been feeling the pressure to upgrade legacy systems due to risks, costs, missing functionality, technical debt, and the growing necessity for digital offerings in every industry. In a complex landscape with bulky IT architectures that have been assembled over decades, how do you know what to modernise and which route to take? Legacy systems are often complex, affect multiple business units, rely on niche skills, and it’s difficult to know where to start.

item.title: Untangling ambiguity with design sprints
item.excerpt:encoded: There are few things as powerful as getting the right people in the same room to unpack a problem. A seemingly simple recipe for problem-solving – a design sprint – does exactly that. This five-day problem-solving technique is becoming a go-to for companies who want to test ideas, develop a new product, or overcome a pressing business concern.

item.title: DevOps: buzzword of the moment
item.excerpt:encoded: DevOps has, in principle, been around for decades. In the early 1980’s, DevOps was a rudimentary end-to-end process. It started with punching holes into cards (representations of code and data), quality assuring their correctness, an then physically transporting the cards to be fed into an IBM mainframe. All the while ensuring that nothing fell out or was blown away, breaking the program and causing delays in delivery.

item.title: Business Intelligence: getting back to thinking inside the box
item.excerpt:encoded: The landscape of Business Intelligence (BI) is shifting. More and more companies are looking for a rapid implementation of a BI solution. While the request to see a return on investment in a solution as quickly as possible is not unfounded, organisations are starting to forget what goes into the foundation of a robust BI solution.

item.title: So you're still running SQL Server 2008?
item.excerpt:encoded: Mainstream support for both SQL Server 2008 and SQL Server 2008 R2 ends in July 2014, so it is important to understand exactly what this means.

item.title: Internet of Things – it’s all about the data
item.excerpt:encoded: Before we can understand the Internet of Things (IoT), we need to know a little more about where the information that is used comes from – after all, the IoT is all about the data!

item.title: Big Data and the Vs
item.excerpt:encoded: ‘Big Data’ may no longer be a buzzword – the concept of Big Data, creating Big Data stores and analysing against these effectively is common practice. However, ‘Big Data’, is still a bit of a ‘fuzzword’, as I like to call it, because there are no industry-accepted or concrete definitions to tick off and go through and finally say, ‘I have Big DataBig Data.’ Lately, I’ve been on a quest to try and understand what this monster is and what would be the key factors that would enable a successful Big Data implementation.

item.title: Why Big Data should be a priority at the moment
item.excerpt:encoded: History has seen a stone age, which was considered an age of innovation, and this stone age was followed by the bronze and iron ages. Many people believe that today, we are living in the ‘data age’.

item.title: My, what Big Data you have!
item.excerpt:encoded: Since the dawning of the digital age, companies have realised the importance of investing in effective Big Data solutions. The real question, however, is WHO do you choose for this Big task?

item.title: Decoding tech buzzwords
item.excerpt:encoded: Every day, we are bombarded with jargon and buzzwords. Each industry has its fair share of jargon, but none so much as the IT industry.

item.title: How data lakes can form a culture of innovation
item.excerpt:encoded: While data lakes are becoming more popular, retaining top talent is key to making the most out of the potential they offer. Creating a culture of innovation is central to this.

item.title: SQL 2016 upgrade
item.excerpt:encoded: Ever since SQL Server 2016 launched, I’ve been saying that it’s a must-have update for anyone running SQL Server 2012 or below, and an upgrade worth considering even for those running SQL Server 2014. That was before SP1 was released. Now, it’s even more of an essential upgrade.

item.title: SQLBits 2017
item.excerpt:encoded: The SQLBits conference in the UK is a highly-rated database conference, focusing on Microsoft technologies.

item.title: First Raspberry Pi Jam comes to South Africa
item.excerpt:encoded: Jointly hosted by RS Components and Entelect Software 40 people attended South Africa's first Raspberry JAM, which kicked off with a keynote address by Eben Upton, the illustrious inventor of the Raspberry Pi.

item.title: How the blockchain can put an end to identity theft
item.excerpt:encoded: Somebody could be using your personal information right now to commit fraud. The scary thing is, you wouldn’t know until it was too late – maybe you get a credit card bill running into the thousands or an exorbitant cellphone account for a number you don’t own.

item.title: What will the skills base of the future look like?
item.excerpt:encoded: With the rise of automation and artificial intelligence, what will jobs of the future look like and how can we future-proof ourselves in this evolving market?

item.title: Pair-programming makes light(er) work of sprint zero
item.excerpt:encoded: Our team believed pair-programming would help implement an MVP at a new client. As well as overcoming key challenges synonymous with 'sprint zero', we uncovered some other benefits along the way too.

item.title: Cut through the hype: How to find value in AI
item.excerpt:encoded: Artificial intelligence (AI) has erupted as an industry trend over the last two years, with a clear confusion about what AI really means to us as consumers and businesses. Are robots coming for all of our jobs? Do we have to prepare for the rise of the machines?

item.title: Do you need a blockchain for that?
item.excerpt:encoded: We’ve heard all about the amazing ways blockchain is going to revolutionise lives and industries – by making supply chain more reliable, banking transactions faster, commodities trading cheaper, and politics more transparent and efficient. There were even questions about why South Africa isn’t using blockchain to safeguard our votes after the recent alleged double-voting controversy during our 2019 general elections. So, if blockchain seemingly has the ability to change everything for the better, why is everyone not using it?

item.title: 4 ways to future-proof your IoT solution, and avoid obsolescence.
item.excerpt:encoded: The Internet of Things (IoT) is evolving rapidly and it’s difficult to say what things may look like in a year or two, much less in the next decade. One of the biggest concerns for organisations is buying what soon becomes functionally or technologically obsolete, but continually deferring to invest in IoT could lead to analysis paralysis.

item.title: A look at feature stores to enable machine learning
item.excerpt:encoded: Working with data is messy and getting it ready for any kind of model building is a painstaking and time-consuming process. Building feature stores is meant to optimize this process for all machine learning teams in an organization.

item.title: How to create the right DevOps culture in your organisation
item.excerpt:encoded: DevOps is a cultural shift. It’s not a matter of simply adopting agile planning or continuous delivery, although those practices are certainly important. Creating a DevOps culture in your organisation is about having shared understanding, communication and collaboration between software engineers and operations, and sharing responsibility for the software they build.

item.title: Understanding bias in artificial intelligence
item.excerpt:encoded: Artificial Intelligence (AI) aims to learn how to do things that people are good at. Humans are great at stringing together complex concepts and harnessing them towards a goal. With that in mind, we’re also moulded by our culture, upbringing, and history. This introduces bias in all humans.

item.title: Security tactics to minimise risks
item.excerpt:encoded: In today’s modern world, almost every business has a digital presence. Some businesses use digital tools to support their core offering and others rely on digital technology as their offering altogether.

item.title: Unpacking the data deluge: 5 reasons why big data projects fail
item.excerpt:encoded: The exponential growth of digital products and services means more data being gathered than ever before: customers, usage, patterns, and problems. With this growth, we have needed to store and manage it all, but more importantly, to figure out how to learn and benefit from it. This has driven the increasing popularity and desire to incorporate machine learning (ML), artificial intelligence (AI) and data science into most new generation systems and products, these big data projects are often ambitious, and often failures.

item.title: PaaS has reignited industry need for custom software
item.excerpt:encoded: The early days of software tooling for businesses were quite unlike what we’re used to now. Decades ago, practically everything was custom-built because it needed to be. Packaged solutions weren’t on the market, and this custom technology is set at the core of most systems today and still performing well.

item.title: Avoiding disaster in a software outsource relationship
item.excerpt:encoded: Comment by Charles Pritchard, CEO of Entelect: We often hear horror stories about companies appointing a software partner and, many millions of rands later, deadlines are missed and excuses are made for non-delivery. I have personally seen it happen with companies that have invested in good business plans, only to be stumped by a software project gone wrong. With big blue-chip companies who have comprehensive support structures, the same can happen: project deadlines keep getting missed, often with unrecoverable costs to the business. So how does one go about choosing the right partner to ensure delivery in software projects?

item.title: Technical debt reversal – development process most effective solution
item.excerpt:encoded: The recent Deloitte Tech Trends 2014 report highlighted one of the key trends for 2014 as ‘Technical Debt Reversal’.

item.title: The 'in-memory' future
item.excerpt:encoded: Recent developments around in-memory analytics and processing are very promising but the underlying technologies need to be understood. These include big data, flash memory, in-memory analytics and in-memory transactional processing.

item.title: How to effectively engage with a software-services provider
item.excerpt:encoded: As a decision maker within your company, you may be faced with the challenge of whether or not to bring in a software-resourcing partner, and how to effectively utilise this partnership to structure a software development division that incorporates your goals, priorities and values.

item.title: Taking cybercrime seriously
item.excerpt:encoded: According to a cybercrime report compiled by global internet security firm, Norton, South Africa lost R3.7 billion in 2012 as a result of cybercrime.

item.title: Building projects and products – is there a difference?
item.excerpt:encoded: When building software solutions, whether internally or outsourced, much of the focus is often on enforcing budget and deadlines, or on risks, such as choosing and implementing the right methodologies, technologies and platforms. Included in this list of pitfalls is a topic that does not get as much airtime as it deserves: understanding the differences between developing a software project and developing a software product.

item.title: Next level analytics competency – part one
item.excerpt:encoded: I recently spoke at the TCI Banking: Big Data and Analytics Conference and my presentation covered shifting to a data-driven culture; developing analytics talent within your organisation; transforming your organisation from a culture, capabilities and technology point of view; and developing a company-wide analytics strategy. With its varied demographic of attendees and presenters, the conference was an ideal setting for such a talk.

item.title: The latest on cybercrime and cybersecurity in South Africa
item.excerpt:encoded: In today’s fast-moving world, technological advances happen faster than legislation can keep up, and will continue to do so for many years to come. As software engineers, the onus lies on us, not only to apply ethical behaviour to the implementation of these new technologies but also to enforce cybersecurity. This can be accomplished only if software companies liaise with governments to enforce new legislation that protects a country’s citizens from falling victim to cybercrimes relating to new technologies.

item.title: Next level analytics competency – part two
item.excerpt:encoded: In the second part of my presentation ‘Scaling your Organisation for the Next Level of Analytics’, which I presented at the TCI Banking: Big Data and Analytics Conference, I took an in-depth look at how to develop skills from a technical and analytical-capabilities point of view. View Part One

item.title: Next level analytics competency – part three
item.excerpt:encoded: In the first two parts of my presentation,‘Scaling your Organisation for the Next Level of Analytics’, which I presented at the TCI Banking: Big Data and Analytics Conference, I looked at the three main pillars of transforming analytics competency within an organisation: culture, technology and capabilities. In the final part of my presentation, I looked at the ideal structure for setting up an analytics centre of excellence. View Parts One and Two

item.title: Delivering a quality service – getting it right
item.excerpt:encoded: Delivering a quality service can make or break a business, especially those in the professional services space where the product is the service. The level of service provided to clients can become a key differentiator and, more often than not, determines whether a client will partner with a service provider for the long-term or, at a minimum, refer the service provider to other potential clients.

item.title: Adaptation in software development processes: Learn, detach and transcend.
item.excerpt:encoded: As software professionals, we embrace best practices and processes that allow us to do our jobs more effectively. But every problem is unique. The ability for a team to 'learn, detach and transcend' can add immeasurable value to the software solutions it delivers.

item.title: Anyone can code, but there are no short cuts to true success.
item.excerpt:encoded: The growth of the technology industry and access to the internet has put software skills development within the reach of many, turning software developers into the rock stars of today. But there are no short cuts. Success as a software engineer takes years of hard work.

item.title: Building a high impact leadership development framework
item.excerpt:encoded: All leadership programmes have a common goal in mind: to develop the next set of leaders inside our organisations. However, we sometimes miss the mark by not delivering a good balance between targeted outcomes compared to the amount of time, effort and money put in.

item.title: A case for unpleasant design in software development
item.excerpt:encoded: UX design can significantly enhance customer experience. But recently a slightly unconventional approach known as 'hostile architecture’ is being used to shape consumer behaviour. So, how can you apply this to UX design effectively?

item.title: Let’s do Agile right
item.excerpt:encoded: Agile was designed to help organisations respond more efficiently in a dynamic marketplace. But to do Agile right requires a culture that encourages innovation and continual learning, and well structured teams.

item.title: Developing a natural interest in STEM through open source software
item.excerpt:encoded: The rise of the open source movement has democratised software. By letting children tinker around with IoT, or encouraging them to contribute to open source projects, we'll be able to stimulate a love of STEM.

item.title: Recovering from failure
item.excerpt:encoded: In the enterprise software development space, the consequence of failure isn’t quite as extreme as was the case for the Mars orbiter, but the stakes are still pretty high. How can you become better at foreseeing failures so that you can turn them into opportunities?

item.title: Kicking off the first squad
item.excerpt:encoded: Kicking off the fist squad is always the hardest. Here are some things we learnt along the way.

item.title: The importance of context in creating a good IA
item.excerpt:encoded: Why context can be a make or break factor in IA

item.title: From mobile first, to customer first – how to build a mobile app with longevity and appeal
item.excerpt:encoded: Mobile adoption is changing the way we do business in South Africa. In 2016, almost 70% of South Africans have browsed the web from a mobile device. Going beyond content, mobile apps are providing an invaluable mechanism for companies to engage with customers and businesses must carefully consider mobile in their digital strategies.

item.title: Beware of bolt-on digital transformations - the short-term thinking trap
item.excerpt:encoded: Digital transformation (DX) is the initiative every corporate talks about and spends vast resources on, it hardly needs to be mentioned at this point. With this level of investment, all these organisations should be well down the path of becoming digital right? A 2017 study done by Forrester Consulting for Microsoft has explored this topic in some depth and highlights that only the minority of enterprises have actually embraced digital transformation as it is envisioned; effectively stating that although there was a strategy (and it got priority), it’s made little to no difference.

item.title: The true value of having a code review culture
item.excerpt:encoded: Code reviews are often seen as a waste of time. This is due to the perception that if you’re not creating code, you’re not being productive. Done right, a code review promotes greater quality software, stronger teamwork, and more inspiration for creativity.

item.title: Stop sabotaging your technology projects: How to communicate requirements effectively
item.excerpt:encoded: Technology teams, departments and industry still hold a reputation for failed projects, where customers and product owners spend too much for too little, or where results pale in comparison to expectations held. We hear about these unmet expectations all the time, followed by budgets blown on project extensions and scope changes. We also hear about customers who “don’t know what they want”, or who “keep changing their minds”. Sound familiar?

item.title: Sizing up UX: Motivating for UX budget and scoping design time effectively
item.excerpt:encoded: Sizing for user experience (UX) is a complex topic and poses challenges to business development and delivery management teams, as well as UX engineers (UXEs) themselves. We’ll look at some of those challenges, as well as methods to overcome them and scope projects effectively.

item.title: Unlocking agile: The power of cross-functional teams
item.excerpt:encoded: We’ve finally reached a post-waterfall world, where iterative problem-solving processes have all but eclipsed traditional models. Almost every tech business, IT department and start-up will tell you they are "wall-to-wall" agile, and have embraced Scrum, Kanban or one of the numerous scaled delivery frameworks. Even so, non-delivery is still common because we've not yet learned to consistently build and drive cross-functional teams.

item.title: Stop disorienting business with elaborate processes
item.excerpt:encoded: As technology specialists, we often find our teams focusing on processes and working models. These processes are the basis of how we solve problems and we often like to share (in detail) how we work. However, even though these elaborate processes are important to achieve the end goal, our stakeholders often have no interest in these models they do not understand.

item.title: The priority gap: Why engineering teams have to stop delivering to themselves in early project milestones
item.excerpt:encoded: The majority of modern technology teams following a Lean-Agile path are familiar with the “deliver early and often” approach. Even though continuous milestone delivery is a common focus, directing efforts to put something in the client’s hands as early as possible to build trust, is not.

item.title: Deconstructing requirements: Why you need to spend more time in the problem space
item.excerpt:encoded: During development, we often forget how important it is to spend enough time exploring and understanding the full context of a problem before charging ahead with new ideas, “game changers” and designs. Time and budgets are frequently wasted on building (and even perfecting) minimum viable products (MVPs) and tech demos, before the actual problem has been adequately explored and understood.

item.title: What are we testing: Chasing metrics versus actual software quality
item.excerpt:encoded: Many engineering teams are focused on redundant input metrics as an indication of the success of “quality assurance” on their technology implementation projects. Are we so busy measuring the number of test cases, pass rates, code coverage and bugs discovered that we have forgotten what real quality means in the eyes of our users?

item.title: Unpacking hypothesis-driven development
item.excerpt:encoded: If you ever had to take science classes in university or high school, you’d be familiar with the concept of educated guesses. Before an experiment, you were likely asked to come up with an assumption that could be tested – a scientific hypothesis. The basic idea of a hypothesis is that there is no pre-determined outcome – and is usually shrouded in uncertainty.

item.title: Is industry becoming irrelevant to digital success?
item.excerpt:encoded: The majority of present-day digital and innovation projects typically involve digitising products and services to combine or reach across traditional sectors. Enterprises are changing (shortening) traditional customer journeys or creating new digital-only products which have no obvious spot on the value chain. There is a theme here: industry irrelevance. The lines are increasingly blurred, and we’re seeing industries learning from each other, as technology components mature and techniques are normalised in a way that can be applied the same way to banking, agriculture, retail and media.

item.title: Platform-oriented IT is universal
item.excerpt:encoded: As options for creating and building digital platforms are expanding and becoming more complex, most enterprises seemingly want to either build or become one. A business platform strategy is an approach to entering a market, offering products and services to it and at the same time offering that channel to competitors looking to reach the same market.

item.title: Proudly South African? Not technically…
item.excerpt:encoded: South Africa has been making waves in the technology innovation world and the country’s wealth of young talent in the technology and software space creates the ideal skills pool for local businesses to tap into.

item.title: Growing pains of an ICT company
item.excerpt:encoded: Software development companies across South Africa are faced with many ongoing challenges but the two that are of utmost importance, are people focused: recruiting and maintaining a strong pool of developers to help fuel the high demand for work in the industry.

item.title: High Performance Teams
item.excerpt:encoded: Earlier this year, Entelect was invited to FNB’s inaugural #CodeFest. The event sees coders prototyping innovative ideas and it culminates in a 24-hour coding marathon, turning those ideas into something tangible.

item.title: What makes a great software engineer?
item.excerpt:encoded: When compared to disciplines such as mechanical, civil and industrial engineering, software engineering as a craft is still young, despite its rapid growth over the last two decades. Much of this growth has been driven by Twitter, Facebook, Google and Microsoft, all of which have generated substantial interest in the field. As a result of this surge in interest, software engineering has become an attractive career option and it draws in people with a wide variety of talent, personality, knowledge and attitude. Given these variations, it is worthwhile looking at the traits that make a great software engineer.

item.title: Employee loyalty programmes: a Band-Aid® for a gaping wound
item.excerpt:encoded: In 2014, Entelect Software won the Deloitte Best Company To Work For award and this year, the company was was awarded with a Gold Achiever Award in the Deloitte Best Company to Work For survey. Of course, the company celebrated these accolades but they also gave them an oppotunity to pause and reflect on the reasons why Entelect has seen a suprisingly low staff churn and high satisfaction rating over the past few years.

item.title: Why candidate liability clauses are bad for business
item.excerpt:encoded: This time of year, graduate recruitment searches start to heat up, and with this comes a number of graduates looking for their first job but unfamiliar with the recruitment process. Candidate Liability Clauses have become a hot topic again recently, partly because they can also be bad for business.

item.title: Using the power of communities to stay relevant
item.excerpt:encoded: Remaining relevant and on top of our industry is hard in a sector that is continuously evolving. But communities can be a powerful place to keep learning and stay ahead of the curve

item.title: BI developers should be treated like gold
item.excerpt:encoded: BI developers, previously considered generalists, are becoming the 'intelligence engineers' of many organisations

item.title: The company breakaway – old-fashioned relic or indispensable business tool?
item.excerpt:encoded: Company breakaways are often dismissed as a few days out of the office, but according to Doug Crawford, the company breakaway is more important than ever.

item.title: Why we fail to find the right job
item.excerpt:encoded: The technology industry is fast-paced and growing exponentially. With so many new jobs emerging all the time, how can you be sure you make a career decision based on the right reasons?

item.title: Performance appraisals: Helping you reach your full potential
item.excerpt:encoded: Performance appraisals can be a stressful time. But if you know how to get the most out of them they can present you with great opportunities to discover your potential.

item.title: How software engineering candidates can create an impact in a highly competitive market
item.excerpt:encoded: The IT industry continues to grow and with it, the demand for software engineering skills. But how can software engineering candidates create in an impact in a highly competitive market.

item.title: The journey to becoming a Data Scientist.
item.excerpt:encoded: The journey to becoming a Data Scientist requires years of proven competencies, a solid track record and a vast breadth and depth of knowledge that is relatively unique

item.title: Loyalty: A morphing concept in the age of a fluid workforce
item.excerpt:encoded: In today's work environment, the concept of loyalty is changing. So how should we redefine our concept of loyalty and what are the benefits of this thinking?

item.title: The importance of socialization at work
item.excerpt:encoded: Socialization in the workplace can help to create camaraderie, break down hierarchical boundaries and foster friendships that help drive employee engagement. How should companies help promote socialization in the workplace, and where should it begin and end?

item.title: Why you should be uncomfortable as a manager
item.excerpt:encoded: Leadership in this fast-moving technology space requires us to occasionally step out of our comfort zone to stay relevant and keep our finger on the pulse of this dynamic industry.

item.title: How software communities can create jobs and stimulate the economy
item.excerpt:encoded: The software industry is growing, which means more jobs. But in South Africa, demand does not meet supply. Informal knowledge environments such as tech and software communities can help bridge this gap in the search for good talent.

item.title: Transitioning from a technical to a management role
item.excerpt:encoded: Moving from a technical to a management role requires new managers to step outside of their comfort zone. What are some of the common challenges and fears facing new managers, and what can leaders of leaders do to support them during the transition?

item.title: Six leadership activities to sustain high-performance software teams
item.excerpt:encoded: Building High Performance Teams is the ultimate goal for many business. But once built, what leadership features need to be in place to sustain its performance for the longer term?

item.title: Differentiate your company with a candidate-centric approach to interviews
item.excerpt:encoded: There are three ways companies can create a 'candidate-centric' approach to the interview process to differentiate their organisation.

item.title: Gearing up for Generation Z
item.excerpt:encoded: Within 12-24 months, we are going to start seeing the first university graduates from the next generation – Gen Z (Gen 2020) – joining the workforce. What does this mean when it comes to growing future leaders and employee retention?

item.title: Make peer review a cornerstone of your SDLC
item.excerpt:encoded: Despite the well-known benefits of peer reviews, teams often struggle to maintain an effective review process when under pressure to deliver. However, there are a number of wider advantages to peer reviews that make them an essential and integral part of your team

item.title: Tech entrepreneurship: you are not prepared
item.excerpt:encoded: Our lives are saturated with apps, websites and digital services. With so much consumer focus on these services, much of the entrepreneurship focus is also on market opportunities created through technology.

item.title: Career lessons from centre stage
item.excerpt:encoded: Some interesting and lesser known parallels between the music industry and the tech industry.

item.title: What have I learned about running remote teams?
item.excerpt:encoded: Remote teams are no longer a future idea. But making sure they are successful requires some very modern approaches to team dynamics

item.title: Nobody Reads Anymore Right?
item.excerpt:encoded: We have a few questions that we ask people joining our company, to get to know them better. One of which is their favourite book. Granted, we are a technology

item.title: Don’t be a commodity in your career. Stop doing and start growing.
item.excerpt:encoded: You could coast through a career of 40 years, or become formidable in 5. This is a look at two mechanisms to stay on the accelerator, grow as a professional and make an impact wherever you are.

item.title: How organisations can empower employees to be the narrators of their story.
item.excerpt:encoded: In a time where access to information, and the noise from external inputs such as social media have never been louder, ensuring your messaging gets maximum exposure, can be challenging.Generally, people tend to trust stories told to them by people that they spend time with and have built relationships with

item.title: The world is changing, So is HR
item.excerpt:encoded: From recruiting new talent, to employee engagement and retention, through to performance management and development, HR functions have never had more tools and resources to support their businesses’ most valuable resources – its people

item.title: Performance reviews which make a real difference
item.excerpt:encoded: Daniel walks confidently down the corridor towards the meeting room booked out for the latest round of bi-annual performance reviews. He is dressed for success, notes in hand and undoubtedly prepared to showcase his achievements over the last six months. In contrast, Joshua looks uninterested, unprepared and ready to leave before he arrives. In both these vastly different review scenarios, there is a lot of preparation needed by a manager and employee in order to get the most out of performance reviews.

item.title: 3 ways to promote better engagement between UX Engineers and Software Engineers
item.excerpt:encoded: Collaboration between user experience (UX) and development is essential for building great solutions. Using the abilities from both disciplines in tandem provides a definite edge that is impossible without collaboration, communication, and compromise.

item.title: Creating a community of collaboration and coding
item.excerpt:encoded: President Barack Obama asked in his State of the Union address that “we live in a time of extraordinary change, change that’s affecting the way we live and the way we work. New technology replaces any job where work can be automated. Workers need more skills to get ahead. These changes aren’t new, and they’re only going to accelerate. So, the question we have to ask ourselves is, ‘How can we make sure everyone has a fair shot at success in this new economy?’” The answer is coding and computer science education.

item.title: The future of the STEM workforce
item.excerpt:encoded: Many companies in the STEM environment, both across Africa and globally, have come to the realisation that striving towards a gender-balanced workforce is an inevitable goal for the future. And although this is what we are aiming towards, there is no simple solution or silver bullet to achieve this.

item.title: 5 lessons in continuity for distributed technology teams
item.excerpt:encoded: Few can argue that 2020 hasn’t been full of worldwide rollercoasters – the biggest being the global COVID-19 pandemic. Due to the accelerated spread of the virus, many organisations have been forced to adapt to a remote working model.

item.title: Innovation thrives in a culture of cultures
item.excerpt:encoded: Innovation as a business concept has many definitions. At its core, the central theme of innovation is the successful delivery of an idea that brings positive value to a company and its customers. However, where there is a large diversity of thought when it comes to the subject, is how to successfully build a “culture of innovation”.

item.title: The changing face of skills in technology teams
item.excerpt:encoded: The way we build software is changing. The way we run our processes is changing. The reason is simple: we have to deliver faster. As pressure to compete for customers in the digital world continues to mount, we have been re-arranging our ways of work to embrace the chaos in modern industry, with shortened delivery cycles.
